facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 93 of 1959 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 93 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal is from the Award dated May 13, 1957, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference I.T. No. 166 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated May 13, 1957, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I.T.  No. 166 of 1955.

facts.text: Dispute was referred to the tribunal by the Government of Bombay on November 17, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: which was referred to the tribunal by the Government of Bombay on November 17, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant is a company manufacturing barrels and drums at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a companypany manufacturing barrels and drums at Bombay.

facts.text: Workmen claimed four months wages including dearness allowance as bonus for the year 1952.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the two matters which are number raised in appeal the workmen claimed  i  four months wages including dearness allowance as bonus for the year 1952

facts.text: Workmen claimed retrospective operation of the wage-scale from March 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and  ii  retrospective operation of the wage-scale to be fixed by the tribunal from March 1, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant agreed to the scale suggested by the tribunal for increase in wages.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the increase in wages, is companycerned, the appellant agreed to the scale suggested by the tribunal

facts.text: Appellant opposed retrospective grant of increased wages.

anchor.surface_text: but it opposed the grant of the increased scale retrospectively

facts.text: Appellant wanted increased wages linked to guaranteed production due to deliberate slowing down of production by workmen in previous years.

anchor.surface_text: and also wanted that the increased wages should be linked to some guaranteed production. The reason for this was that the appellant felt that there had been deliberate slowing down of production by the workmen in the previous years.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal found some justification in appellant's contention of considerable go-slow affecting production.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal was of opinion that there was some justification in the appellants companytention that there had been companysiderable go-slow which had affected production.

facts.text: Tribunal ordered retrospective effect to wage increase from June 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Taking that into account it ordered that retrospective effect should be given to its order which was passed on May 13, 1957 from June 1, 1956.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded five months basic wages as bonus.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has awarded five months basic wages by way of bonus.

facts.text: Gross profit found by tribunal is Rs. 5.05 lacs, not challenged.

anchor.surface_text: The gross profit found by the tribunal is number challenged, namely, Rs. 5.05 lacs.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed Rs. 1.36 lacs as depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has then allowed Rs. 1.36 lacs as depreciation,

facts.text: Available surplus after calculations is Rs. 1.92 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: Six per cent. per annum interest on the paid-up capital along with four per cent. interest on the working capital companyes to Rs. 16,000, leaving an available surplus of Rs. 1.92 lacs.

facts.text: Bonus of five months basic wages amounts to Rs. 91,000 according to tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Out of this, the tribunal has allowed five months basic wages as bonus which according to its calculations companyes to Rs. 91,000,

facts.text: Appellant appropriated Rs. 3.16 lacs towards depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: What it had done was to appropriate Rs. 3.16 lacs towards depreciation,

facts.text: Workmen in Ex. U-4 allowed Rs. 40,000 towards rehabilitation.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention is drawn, however, to the figures filed by the workmen in Ex. U-4 in which Rs. 40,000 has been allowed towards rehabilitation.

facts.text: Appellant assessed to income-tax of Rs. 2.35 lacs after tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it is urged that according to the income-tax assessment which was actually made in this case sometime after the order of the tribunal, the appellant has been assessed to income-tax amounting to Rs. 2.35 lacs.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected retrospective operation from March 1952 to May 1956.

anchor.surface_text: in any case the tribunal rejected the claim of the workmen for retrospective operation for the period of over four years from March 1952 to May 1956

concepts.interpretation: Income-tax deducted is notional based on formula calculations (7 annas per rupee on net profits after depreciation), immaterial what actual assessment is; tribunal concerned with formula's notional figures, not income-tax department's actual allowance of expenses.

anchor.surface_text: bonus for the year 1952 and  ii  retrospective operation of the order of the Industrial Tribunal relating to increase in wages. The appellant is a companypany manufacturing barrels and drums at Bombay. There was a dispute between the appellant and its workmen about a number of matters, which was referred to the tribunal by the Government of Bombay on November 17, 1955.

issues.text: retrospective operation of the order of the Industrial Tribunal relating to increase in wages

anchor.surface_text: retrospective operation of the order of the Industrial Tribunal relating to increase in wages. The appellant is a companypany manufacturing barrels and drums at Bombay. There was a dispute between the appellant and its workmen about a number of matters, which was referred to the tribunal by the Government of Bombay on November 17, 1955. In respect of the two matters which are now raised in appeal the workmen claimed (i) four months wages including dearness allowance as bonus for the year 1952 and (ii) retrospective operation of the wage-scale to be fixed by the tribunal from March 1, 1952.

issues.text: whether the tribunal could have awarded anything more than what the workmen claimed

anchor.surface_text: The first contention in this connection is that the workmen had only claimed four months basic wages and the tribunal could not have awarded anything more than what the workmen claimed. This in our opinion is incorrect. The workmen had claimed four months wages including dearness allowance as bonus. Five months basic wages which the tribunal has allowed are admittedly less than the claim put forward  namely, four months wages including dearness allowance .

issues.text: whether the tribunal was justified in awarding as much as five months basic wages on the basis of the Full Bench formula

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the tribunal was justified in awarding as much as five months basic wages on the basis of the Full Bench formula, which is generally applied to these matters. The gross profit found by the tribunal is not challenged, namely, Rs. 5.05 lacs. The tribunal has then allowed Rs. 1.36 lacs as depreciation, leaving a balance of Rs. 3.69, lacs. Deducting income-tax from this at seven annas in a rupee  i.e. Rs. 1.61 lacs , we are left with a balance of Rs. 2.08 lacs.

issues.text: whether the tribunal has taken into account anything for rehabilitation

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, however, draws our attention to two circumstances in this connection. In the first place it urges that the tribunal has not taken into account anything for rehabilitation. But it may be mentioned that the appellant had proved no rehabilitation amount as such. What it had done was to appropriate Rs. 3.16 lacs towards depreciation, which of course was not the proper amount of notional normal depreciation, which is allowable under the formula.

issues.text: whether income-tax payable has to be the actual income-tax assessed or the notional figure calculated according to the Full Bench formula

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it is urged that according to the income-tax assessment which was actually made in this case sometime after the order of the tribunal, the appellant has been assessed to income-tax amounting to Rs. 2.35 lacs. The appellant claims that it should be allowed this entire amount and not the notional figure calculated by us, namely, Rs. 1.61 lacs as income-tax.

arguments.claim: Tribunal should not have given any retrospective effect to wage increase due to considerable go-slow by workmen

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contention before us is that the tribunal having found some justification in its contention that there had been considerable go-slow should not have given retrospective effect at all to the order relating to the increase in wages.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ng that the reference was made in November 1955 in any case the tribunal rejected the claim of the workmen for retrospective operation for the period

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal fully considered go-slow, limited retrospective to June 1 1956 post-reference, rejected longer claim from 1952

arguments.claim: Five months basic wages bonus justified under Full Bench formula calculations

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the tribunal was justified in awarding as much as five months basic wages on the basis of the Full Bench formula, which is generally applied to these matters. The gross profit found by the tribunal is not challenged, namely, Rs. 5.05 lacs.

arguments.claim: No interference with tribunal's retrospective wage order from June 1 1956

anchor.surface_text: This matter has been considered fully by the tribunal and it came to the conclusion that increase in wages should be granted from June 1, 1956. This could hardly be called retrospective considering that the reference was made in November 1955

arguments.claim: Full Bench formula uses notional income-tax based on formula profits, not actual assessment

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that for the purpose of the Full Bench formula, the income-tax payable has to be deducted on the figures worked out according to the formula and it is immaterial what the actual income -tax paid is-whether more or less.

arguments.claim: Available surplus after Full Bench deductions supports five months bonus without interference

anchor.surface_text: Out of this, the tribunal has allowed five months basic wages as bonus which according to its calculations comes to Rs. 91,000, leaving Rs. 1.01 lacs. There will be a rebate of Rs. 40,000 on this sum, leaving a total of Rs. 1.41 lacs with the appellant.

arguments.claim: Some justification in go-slow affecting production but still order limited retrospective

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal was of opinion that there was some justification in the appellants contention that there had been considerable go-slow which had affected production. Taking that into account it ordered that retrospective effect should be given to its order

arguments.court_reasoning: Court defers to tribunal's reasoned discretionary fixing of date

holdings.text: In the circumstances we see no reason for interference with the order of the tribunal fixing the date as June 1, 1956, from which the increased wages should come into force.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we see no reason for interference with the order of the tribunal fixing the date as June 1, 1956, from which the increased wages should come into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal fully considered go-slow evidence, rejected longer retrospective claim from 1952, limited to post-reference date June 1956 warranting deference under Art 136.

holdings.text: In the circumstances the tribunal certainly had jurisdiction to award what it has awarded to the workmen.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the tribunal certainly had jurisdiction to award what it has awarded to the workmen. The next question is whether the tribunal was justified in awarding as much as five months basic wages on the basis of the Full Bench formula, which is generally applied to these matters.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Workmen's claim of 4 months wages incl. DA exceeds value of awarded 5 months basic wages; broad jurisdiction allows equivalent or lesser relief form.

holdings.text: On these figures, the bonus awarded by the tribunal cannot be interfered with.

anchor.surface_text: On these figures, the bonus awarded by the tribunal cannot be interfered with. The appellant, however, draws our attention to two circumstances in this connection. In the first place it urges that the tribunal has not taken into account anything for rehabilitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gross profits Rs 5.05 lacs minus depreciation Rs 1.36 lacs, notional IT Rs 1.61 lacs, interest Rs 0.16 lacs yields surplus Rs 1.92 lacs; 5 months bonus Rs 0.91 lacs leaves Rs 1.01 lacs even after concessions.

holdings.text: There is thus no reason to interfere with the award of bonus on this ground.

anchor.surface_text: Even accepting this concession by the workmen and deducting it from the figures given by us above, the appellant would still be left with Rs. 1.01 lacs after paying five months basic wages as bonus. There is thus no reason to interfere with the award of bonus on this ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proved rehabilitation; appellant's Rs 3.16 lacs depreciation appropriation improper; even conceding respondents' Rs 40,000 leaves sufficient surplus post-bonus.

holdings.text: We are of opinion that for the purpose of the Full Bench formula, the income-tax payable has to be deducted on the figures worked out according to the formula and it is immaterial what the actual income-tax paid is-whether more or less.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that for the purpose of the Full Bench formula, the income-tax payable has to be deducted on the figures worked out according to the formula and it is immaterial what the actual income -tax paid is-whether more or less. In this particular case, the income-tax appears to be more because certain items which were challenged by the workmen but were allowed as proper expense by the tribunal have apparently not been allowed as proper expense by the income-tax department.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Formula mandates notional IT (7 annas/rupee on post-depreciation profits) irrespective of actual assessment; tribunal applies formula figures, not IT dept allowances.

holdings.text: There is no ground therefore for interference-with the award of bonus for this reason either.

anchor.surface_text: The industrial tribunal, however, is not concerned directly with what the income tax authorities assess as actual income-tax in a particular year it is concerned with working out the Full Bench formula in accordance with its notional calculations and this is what has been done in this case. There is no ground therefore for interference-with the award of bonus for this reason either.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal correctly applied notional Full Bench formula calculations, independent of actual IT assessment.
